DISCHARGE LABS 07:20AM BLOOD WBC-7.7 RBC-4.36 Hgb-13.1 Hct-39.8 MCV-91 MCH-30.0 MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.8 RDWSD-49.9* Plt 07:20AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-28* Creat-1.2* Na-139 K-4.5 Cl-98 HCO3-25 AnGap-16 07:20AM BLOOD Calcium-9.3 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.2 Brief Hospital Course: Ms. is a year old woman with history heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, coronary artery disease s/p RCA stent, paroxysmal afib, tachy-brady syndrome s/p PPM in , and hypothyroidism who presented with chest pain, felt to be musculoskeletal. She was found to have hypoxemic respiratory failure, felt secondary to pneumonia and HFpEF exacerbation. She was treated with levofloxacin and increased Lasix, with resolution of hypoxia. ACUTE ISSUES: # Hypoxemic respiratory failure # Community acquired pneumonia # Acute on chronic HFpEF: Patient presented with new oxygen requirement on admission, felt secondary pneumonia and acute on chronic HFpEF after patient received IV fluid in the ED. She was treated with a 7 day course of levofloxacin [] and diuresis with IV Lasix followed by increased dose of PO Lasix. At discharge, she was euvolemic on exam and breathing comfortably on room air. Her ambulatory oxygen saturation ws 91-93%. She will follow up with cardiology and pulmonology as an outpatient with repeat chest xray to ensure resolution of pleural effusion and consolidation. # AFib with RVR: # Tachy-brady syndrome: On admission, pacemaker interrogation was notable for several episodes of afib with RVR. She had episodes of Afib with RVR during admission as well, likely secondary to pneumonia and volume overload as above. She remained hemodynamically stable and denied any symptoms during these episodes other than occasional "head heaviness". She was unaware of most of these episodes. Given prior bradycardia and hypotension with more aggressive rate control, she was continued on home verapamil and dose-reduced apixaban (CHADS-VASC 3). She will follow up with cardiology as an outpatient. # Musculoskeletal chest pain Patient presented with three days of intermittent chest pain that improved with Tylenol. Her chest pain was focal, left-sided, and reproducible with palpation, most consistent with musculoskeletal pain. EKG showed no evidence of ischemia, and troponin/CKMB were negative x 2. Chest pain resolved during admission. Her home atorvastatin and apixaban were continued. She is not on aspirin at home to decrease bleeding risk. # GERD Patient complained of burning pain in epigastric area with eating, consistent with GERD. She was started on omeprazole 20mg and Maalox prn, with improvement in symptoms. CHRONIC ISSUES: # Intermittent RUQ pain: Patient had RUQ pain intermittently with eating. RUQ ultrasound was unremarkable. She had a similar episode several weeks ago, which was felt to be sphincter of odi dysfunction. Patient may benefit from HIDA scan as outpatient if pain continues. # Hypothyroidism: TSH 4.1. Continued home levothyroxine. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). Discharge Instructions: Dear Ms. , You were admitted to the hospital because you were having chest pain. WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL? You had blood tests which showed that your chest pain was not coming from your heart. The chest pain was probably coming from the muscles and cartilage in your chest. This was treated with Tylenol and lidocaine patches. You were diagnosed with a pneumonia and a flare of your heart failure. You were treated with antibiotics, extra Lasix (the water pill), and extra oxygen. You had some stomach pain with eating. This might be caused by acid reflux. You were started on a medicine called omeprazole and Maalox as needed for this. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? Please call Dr. office at to make a follow up appointment this coming week. You will need to see the lung doctors and get another chest xray in 6 weeks. The lung doctors are working to set up an appointment for you. If you don't hear from them by , please call them at to make an appointment. Please take all your medicines as described in this paperwork. Please keep all your follow up appointments as listed below. Please weigh yourself every morning. Call your doctor if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Your weight at discharge was 130 pounds. It was a pleasure to participate in your care. We wish you all the best! Sincerely, Your team Followup Instructions:
